urn:contentItem:5YBH-XP71-F06X-W0M4-00000-00Simpler is better for fintechs breaking into banking2020-03-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:19ZLexisNexisSimpler is better for fintechs breaking into bankingTodd H. Baker

For years it seemed that no fintech - however well run - would find a way to become a "real" bank.

The reasons were depressingly familiar: risk-averse regulators, approval timelines too lengthy for young companies, control rules that ignored changes in the investment world, to name a few. It got so bad that the Columbia University's Richman Center in November to the problem.

Now, just three months later, the world has changed. In recent weeks, two pioneering fintechs - LendingClub and Varo Money - have proven that direct participation in the banking system is possible for digital financial providers.

It's looking like 2020 will be the tipping point for fintech movement into the regulated banking space.

Just this week, LendingClub said it is , marking the first time a major fintech lender is purchasing a bank. The deal is a strategic and financial home run for LendingClub, combining the online consumer lender with a modern, flexible national deposit platform.

It sets the company on a path for long-term success by stabilizing its core funding, adding needed flexibility to its business model and stripping away costly intermediaries. This is something other fintech lenders should emulate.

Assuming the deal is approved by regulators, LendingClub would be able to fund its own loan warehouse with deposits, a big savings as compared to borrowing from bank lenders.

Because it would have a bank balance sheet to work with, LendingClub could be far pickier in deciding when, and at what price, it sells its loans. And the deal completely eliminates the need to pay its current bank partner, WebBank, for its services in originating loans.

Buying Radius will also help LendingClub turn its loyal customer base into a source of new growth. Today, LendingClub is great at generating new online loan customers, but it has little to offer them beyond its core installment loan products. With the Radius deal, LendingClub will be able to offer its customers a complete suite of financial tools and in time, more automated ways to help customers manage their financial lives seamlessly.

LendingClub's deal follows closely behind a recent (but long-delayed) decision by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. to approve Varo Money's application for deposit . This was a which many hope will provide the roadmap for future de novo fintech applicants to take the same path, but in less time.

Varo's dual-track online banking strategy looks pretty good in retrospect. Varo built a large with a number of revenue streams while it was pursuing a bank license.

Varo's customer base and brand presence - plus its cloud-based modern IT core -will give it a big head start over other startup banks.

Of course, there are still obstacles ahead for both LendingClub and Varo.

LendingClub will need to keep regulators happy with its growth plans, integration roadmap and market strategy for Radius. And Varo Money will have to meet the challenge of moving 1 million synthetic fintech bank customers from its existing partner bank to its new deposit platform - all while building out its lending and fee businesses. Both these things seem achievable.

There are a couple of points that other fintechs interested in banking should keep in mind when considering the implications of LendingClub and Varo Money.

The first is that simpler is better: both LendingClub and Varo followed traditional paths to bank ownership by either acquiring an existing insured bank or starting a new bank through the de novo process.

Neither tried for the more exotic or the Comptroller of the Currency's new fintech charter, . That turned out to be a smart move.

Although it is rumored that the FDIC will soon approve a couple of new ILC charters, even successful ILC applicants are likely to run into opposition from Congress and small bankers, who worry that big tech companies can to gain a banking license.

There is nothing in the law to prevent Amazon, Google, Microsoft or Facebook from acquiring one of these new ILCs since the Bank Holding Company Act doesn't apply to that charter. The political stakes and risks for ILC applicants have become higher than ever.

The second thing to keep in mind is that while the fintech banking door is open, not everyone can enter.

Both Varo and LendingClub presented themselves to regulators, particularly the FDIC, as "fintech" rather than "tech-fin."

Varo Money is led by a strong team of experienced bankers, and LendingClub's executive ranks are full of the same, soon to be supplemented by Radius Bank's management team. These are people with long histories in regulated banking, and the credibility that goes along with that.

This contrasts with the more tech-first companies like Robinhood that followed the "move fast, break things" ethos of Silicon Valley when they sought a bank charter.

The FDIC is focused on risk control.

urn:contentItem:5Y84-2H91-JCRW-52TP-00000-00Simpler is better for fintechs breaking into banking2020-02-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:19ZLexisNexisSimpler is better for fintechs breaking into bankingTodd H. Baker

For years it seemed that no fintech - however well run - would find a way to become a "real" bank.

The reasons were depressingly familiar: risk-averse regulators, approval timelines too lengthy for young companies, control rules that ignored changes in the investment world, to name a few. It got so bad that the Columbia University's Richman Center in November to the problem.

Now, just three months later, the world has changed. In recent weeks, two pioneering fintechs - LendingClub and Varo Money - have proven that direct participation in the banking system is possible for digital financial providers.

It's looking like 2020 will be the tipping point for fintech movement into the regulated banking space.

Just this week, LendingClub said it is , marking the first time a major fintech lender is purchasing a bank. The deal is a strategic and financial home run for LendingClub, combining the online consumer lender with a modern, flexible national deposit platform.

It sets the company on a path for long-term success by stabilizing its core funding, adding needed flexibility to its business model and stripping away costly intermediaries. This is something other fintech lenders should emulate.

Assuming the deal is approved by regulators, LendingClub would be able to fund its own loan warehouse with deposits, a big savings as compared to borrowing from bank lenders.

Because it would have a bank balance sheet to work with, LendingClub could be far pickier in deciding when, and at what price, it sells its loans. And the deal completely eliminates the need to pay its current bank partner, WebBank, for its services in originating loans.

Buying Radius will also help LendingClub turn its loyal customer base into a source of new growth. Today, LendingClub is great at generating new online loan customers, but it has little to offer them beyond its core installment loan products. With the Radius deal, LendingClub will be able to offer its customers a complete suite of financial tools and in time, more automated ways to help customers manage their financial lives seamlessly.

LendingClub's deal follows closely behind a recent (but long-delayed) decision by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. to approve Varo Money's application for deposit . This was a which many hope will provide the roadmap for future de novo fintech applicants to take the same path, but in less time.

Varo's dual-track online banking strategy looks pretty good in retrospect. Varo built a large with a number of revenue streams while it was pursuing a bank license.

Varo's customer base and brand presence - plus its cloud-based modern IT core -will give it a big head start over other startup banks.

Of course, there are still obstacles ahead for both LendingClub and Varo.

LendingClub will need to keep regulators happy with its growth plans, integration roadmap and market strategy for Radius. And Varo Money will have to meet the challenge of moving 1 million synthetic fintech bank customers from its existing partner bank to its new deposit platform - all while building out its lending and fee businesses. Both these things seem achievable.

There are a couple of points that other fintechs interested in banking should keep in mind when considering the implications of LendingClub and Varo Money.

The first is that simpler is better: both LendingClub and Varo followed traditional paths to bank ownership by either acquiring an existing insured bank or starting a new bank through the de novo process.

Neither tried for the more exotic or the Comptroller of the Currency's new fintech charter, . That turned out to be a smart move.

Although it is rumored that the FDIC will soon approve a couple of new ILC charters, even successful ILC applicants are likely to run into opposition from Congress and small bankers, who worry that big tech companies can to gain a banking license.

There is nothing in the law to prevent Amazon, Google, Microsoft or Facebook from acquiring one of these new ILCs since the Bank Holding Company Act doesn't apply to that charter. The political stakes and risks for ILC applicants have become higher than ever.

The second thing to keep in mind is that while the fintech banking door is open, not everyone can enter.

Both Varo and LendingClub presented themselves to regulators, particularly the FDIC, as "fintech" rather than "tech-fin."

Varo Money is led by a strong team of experienced bankers, and LendingClub's executive ranks are full of the same, soon to be supplemented by Radius Bank's management team. These are people with long histories in regulated banking, and the credibility that goes along with that.

This contrasts with the more tech-first companies like Robinhood that followed the "move fast, break things" ethos of Silicon Valley when they sought a bank charter.

The FDIC is focused on risk control.

urn:contentItem:5WRH-SV81-JBJ7-N14H-00000-00Sims defends ACCC crackdown on big tech2019-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:19ZLexisNexisSims defends ACCC crackdown on big techPaul Smith

The ACCC chairman has dismissed concerns that some of its proposals to crimp the power of Facebook and Google will inhibit innovation and expose tech secrets.

Australian Competition and Consumer Commission chairman Rod Sims has stood by his organisation's proposal to place greater regulatory scrutiny on the algorithms that run big tech platforms such as Google and Facebook, and to police any future local acquisitions by the tech giants, saying critics have either misunderstood the plans or overstated the repercussions.

The topics were raised in a collection of 23 recommendations in the regulator's landmark Digital Platform Inquiry final report, which was   released at the end of last month, but have since attracted criticism from members of the local tech scene.

Mr Sims spoke with The Australian Financial Review a week after the mammoth 619-page report landed, saying he had largely received strong support for the report's suggestions, but recognised concerns were being raised about the practicality of the regulator assessing the algorithms used to determine how advertising and content (such as search results) are displayed, and also about restricting M&A activity.

Both Facebook and   Google had previously pushed back against oversight of their inner tech workings, saying it was either impractical or would allow bad actors to game the system. At last week's Financial Review Innovation Summit, Airtree Ventures founder Daniel Petre said the idea of creating an algorithmic committee was "ridiculous".

"Advertisers decide whether the price they pay for advertising is fair or not on an ROI [return on investment] basis. We don't need any committee of algorithmic geniuses to tell us whether the algorithm is useful or not. That's a complete joke and should be completely cast aside," Mr Petre said.

Mr Sims said critics of the plan seemed to be responding to speculation about what might happen, rather than what was in the report. The report proposes a specialist digital platforms branch be established within the ACCC to develop expertise in digital markets and the use of algorithms, and take action to enforce competition and consumer laws.

"The point in relation to what was referred to as an algorithm review committee or something like that, there's no such reference in the report, much less any recommendations to that effect," Mr Sims said.

"What we'll be doing is, either in response to complaints from businesses, or off our own bat, be just testing things with the algorithms by doing what anybody could do, which is just put requests to the algorithms and see what happens."

He said the ACCC wouldn't be looking to get a detailed view of how the Google and Facebook algorithms worked, rather they would be assessing the results of the sites, either off its own bat or as a result of complaints from others.

New ombudsman

The ACCC report said Google and Facebook had both the ability and incentive to favour their own related businesses, or commercial partners at the expense of other business users of their platforms.

It said the opacity of their key algorithms meant there was significant potential for "self-preferencing" to substantially lessen competition.

This was highlighted in a 2017 European Commission ruling that found Google had systematically given prominent placement to its own comparison shopping service Google Shopping, by demoting rival comparison shopping services in its search results.

"If it's a complaint about Google, for example, referencing its own travel advisory business to the detriment of Flight Centre, for example, then you can easily put in a lot of searches and find out what the output from the algorithm is," Mr Sims said.

"Then we would have the ability to, in a targeted way, find from Google, why that's happening ... we would have the information-gathering powers to do that, then we would determine whether or not there was anti-competitive behaviour or not."

Mr Sims said the ACCC would need fresh funding in the region of $5 million to establish its new division, and that it would work in concert with a new independent ombudsman to resolve complaints and disputes between businesses or consumers and digital platforms.

He said Australian companies or consumers that found themselves on the wrong side of a decision or problem from Google or Facebook had no real possibility of redress as they had no idea who to talk to, and no ability to get responses.

"This would first of all, give them an avenue to talk Facebook and Google, which they can't now because it's just not possible," Mr Sims said.

"It is very faceless and that is a deliberate tactic. But I think we've got to make sure that they have contacts in Australia that you can contact, and then separately, there would be an ombudsman, if it got that far, that could resolve the issue."

Anti-merger proposal controversial

From a commercial perspective, one of the most controversial part of the ACCC report was the proposal to change merger laws to add competition factors to question whether an acquisition was removing a potential competitor and whether assets, like the kind of data, held by an acquired company would reduce competition from the market.

As well as Mr Petre, a number of start-up founders and other members of the local tech scene have warned that restricting the ability for local companies to get acquired by tech giants could stymie the growth prospects of the Australian tech sector.

On Friday, StartupAUS chief executive Alex McCauley said many start-ups in the tech sector relied on strong merger and acquisition opportunities to build their company's investment case.

He said that, if acquisitions became more difficult in Australia, it would inevitably weaken the ability to attract investment and reduce the number of high-quality founders choosing to build businesses here.

"This ironically would crimp opportunity for new competition from local firms, despite the recommendations aiming to enhance the competitive environment in Australian tech," Mr McCauley said.

"Lots of start-up founders deliberately target this sort of acquisition as a way to reach a profitable exit. Making this harder or less likely would reduce the ability for successful entrepreneurs to recycle capital back into their next enterprise.

"The intention here - to help Australian companies - is a good one. But the bottom line is that making it harder for startups to get acquired isn't good for startups and it isn't good for the economy."

Mr Sims said he had faced similar criticisms when previously expressing concerns about big banks looking to buy up fintech start-ups, but that close regulatory observation was necessary to avoid monopolistic behaviour.

He said the assessment that an acquisition would substantially lessen competition was a high bar for the ACCC to get over in deciding to block a deal, but that it wouldn't shy away from taking a tough approach.

"Taking it to the extreme, if all start-ups got acquired by either the big four banks, or Google and Facebook, then what a terrible outcome that is. I mean, that means there's no competitive threat ever to the incumbents, that's a shocking outcome," Mr Sims said.

" I understand it's a matter of balance, but it has got to be something that substantially lessens competition, and if it does, we will definitely take action."

urn:contentItem:5VSF-B3M1-F0J6-J3NS-00000-00Sims rebuffs Zuckerberg appeal for global laws;SOCIAL MEDIA2019-04-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:19ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Sims rebuffs Zuckerberg appeal for global lawsSOCIAL MEDIAJennifer Duke

Australian competition tsar Rod Sims has rebuffed Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg's near-term hopes for national governments to treat social media giants and personal data in the same way with globally consistent laws.

The Facebook chairman published an opinion article in The Washington Post, which is also running in the Herald today, pushing for more regulation around harmful content, consistent rules for election integrity and the ability for consumers to move their data from one platform to another.

He also backed a standard global framework for data and privacy rather than what he described as "regulation that varies significantly by country and state [to] ensure that the internet does not get fractured". Mr Zuckerberg added that this framework could take the form of a worldwide roll out of the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR).

Mr Sims, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission chairman, said that getting a global agreement about data protection would be "a much better" way to manage the issue and welcomed Mr Zuckerberg's "recognition" that big tech companies such as Facebook and Google "have to be accountable for what people see [on their platforms]".

"But in the short term that can be very slow and we can't always wait for global agreement because the issues are too pressing," he added. "Countries may have to move on their own, and alignment will come later as these issues can't wait for the slowest country."

Mr Sims spent three days last week at the American Bar Association's anti-trust conference speaking to the European Commission, US Department of Justice and US Fair Trade commission among other competition bodies.

Since meeting with the global competition regulators, he said that worldwide regulatory alignment was unlikely in the short term and that the ACCC would push ahead with its world-first inquiry into the digital platforms' impact on advertising and traditional media. A final report is due in June.

The final report would likely include "recommendations that are largely aligned with GDPR but [there will be] important differences as well," he said.

"If you seek global alignment, it's fantastic in theory, and great if it could be done, but each country has to move according to its own views, according to the solutions to the problems."

Facebook and other digital giants like Google are under increased scrutiny in many countries, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison recently threatening prison time and billions of dollars in fines if extremist content isn't quickly removed.

The new legislation was in response to a livestream video of the attacks on Christchurch mosques broadcast on Facebook by the alleged gunman and may be presented to the G20 summit in June in a move that signals the Australian government's willingness to work on a global basis for concerns such as enforcement.

urn:contentItem:5WRH-SXY1-JD34-V00C-00000-00Sims stands firm on FAANG mergers and algorithm tests2019-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:19ZLexisNexisCOMPUTERSPg. 19Sims stands firm on FAANG mergers and algorithm testsPaul Smith

Exclusive Regulator answers critics of oversight plan.

Australian Competition and Consumer Commission chairman Rod Sims has stood by his organisation's proposal to place greater regulatory scrutiny on the algorithms that run big tech platforms such as Google and Facebook, and to police any future local acquisitions by the tech giants, saying critics have either misunderstood the plans or overstated the repercussions.

The topics were raised in a collection of 23 recommendations in the regulator's landmark Digital Platform Inquiry final report, which was released at the end of last month, but have since attracted criticism from members of the local tech scene.

Mr Sims spoke with The Australian Financial Review a week after the mammoth 619-page report landed, saying he had largely received strong support for the report's suggestions, but recognised concerns were being raised about the practicality of the regulator assessing the algorithms used to determine how advertising and content (such as search results) are displayed, and also about restricting M&A activity.

Both Facebook and Google had previously pushed back against oversight of their inner tech workings, saying it was either impractical or would allow bad actors to game the system. At last week's Financial Review Innovation Summit, Airtree Ventures founder Daniel Petre said the idea of creating an algorithmic committee was "ridiculous".

"Advertisers decide whether the price they pay for advertising is fair or not on an ROI [return on investment] basis. We don't need any committee of algorithmic geniuses to tell us whether the algorithm is useful or not. That's a complete joke and should be completely cast aside," Mr Petre said.

Mr Sims said critics of the plan seemed to be responding to speculation about what might happen, rather than what was in the report. The report proposes a specialist digital platforms branch be established within the ACCC to develop expertise in digital markets and the use of algorithms, and take action to enforce competition and consumer laws.

"The point in relation to what was referred to as an algorithm review committee or something like that, there's no such reference in the report, much less any recommendations to that effect," Mr Sims said.

"What we'll be doing is, either in response to complaints from businesses, or off our own bat, be just testing things with the algorithms by doing what anybody could do, which is just put requests to the algorithms and see what happens."

He said the ACCC wouldn't be looking to get a detailed view of how the Google and Facebook algorithms worked, rather they would be assessing the results of the sites, either off its own bat or as a result of complaints from others.

The ACCC report said Google and Facebook had both the ability and incentive to favour their own related businesses, or commercial partners at the expense of other business users of their platforms.

It said the opacity of their key algorithms meant there was significant potential for "self-preferencing" to substantially lessen competition.

This was highlighted in a 2017 European Commission ruling that found Google had systematically given prominent placement to its own comparison shopping service Google Shopping, by demoting rival comparison shopping services in its search results.

"If it's a complaint about Google, for example, referencing its own travel advisory business to the detriment of Flight Centre, for example, then you can easily put in a lot of searches and find out what the output from the algorithm is," Mr Sims said.

"Then we would have the ability to, in a targeted way, find from Google, why that's happening ... we would have the information-gathering powers to do that. Then we would determine whether or not there was anti-competitive behaviour or not."

Mr Sims said the ACCC would need fresh funding in the region of $5 million to establish its new division, and that it would work in concert with a new independent ombudsman to resolve complaints and disputes between businesses or consumers and digital platforms.

Australian companies or consumers that found themselves on the wrong side of a decision or problem from Google or Facebook had no real possibility of redress as they had no idea who to talk to, or ability to get responses.

"This would, first of all, give them an avenue to talk to Facebook and Google, which they can't now because it's just not possible," Mr Sims said.

"It is very faceless and that is a deliberate tactic. But I think we've got to make sure that they have contacts in Australia that you can contact, and then separately, there would be an ombudsman, if it got that far, that could resolve the issue."

From a commercial perspective, one of the most controversial parts of the ACCC report was the proposal to change merger laws to add competition factors to question whether an acquisition was removing a potential competitor and whether assets, like the kind of data, held by an acquired company would reduce competition from the market.

As well as Mr Petre, a number of start-up founders and other members of the local tech scene have warned that restricting the ability for local companies to get acquired by tech giants could stymie the growth prospects of the Australian tech sector.

On Friday, StartupAUS chief executive Alex McCauley said many start-ups in the tech sector relied on strong merger and acquisition opportunities to build their company's investment case.

He said that, if acquisitions became more difficult in Australia, it would inevitably weaken the ability to attract investment and reduce the number of high-quality founders choosing to build businesses here.

"This ironically would crimp opportunity for new competition from local firms, despite the recommendations aiming to enhance the competitive environment in Australian tech," Mr McCauley said.

"Lots of start-up founders deliberately target this sort of acquisition as a way to reach a profitable exit. Making this harder or less likely would reduce the ability for successful entrepreneurs to recycle capital back into their next enterprise.

"The intention here, to help Australian companies, is a good one. But the bottom line is making it harder for start-ups to get acquired isn't good for start-ups and it isn't good for the economy."

Mr Sims said he had faced similar criticisms when previously expressing concerns about big banks looking to buy up fintech start-ups, but that close regulatory observation was necessary to avoid monopolistic behaviour.

He said the assessment that an acquisition would substantially lessen competition was a high bar for the ACCC to get over in deciding to block a deal, but that it wouldn't shy away from taking a tough approach.

"Taking it to the extreme, if all start-ups got acquired by either the big four banks, or Google and Facebook, then what a terrible outcome that is. I mean, that means there's no competitive threat ever to the incumbents. That's a shocking outcome," Mr Sims said.

"I understand it's a matter of balance, but it has got to be something that substantially lessens competition, and if it does, we will definitely take action."

urn:contentItem:60K4-0721-F0J6-J2HP-00000-00SIMS TAKES ON THE TECH TITANS2020-08-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:19ZLexisNexisMARKETING & MEDIAPg. 31SIMS TAKES ON THE TECH TITANSMax Mason

News content Has the ACCC chief's attempt to get Google and Facebook to pay fairly for journalism cracked the digital code? Max Mason reports.

Competition tsar Rod Sims is not the first to try to find a way to force Facebook and Google to pay for the value they get from journalism on their platforms.

And the draft of a compulsory code of conduct - which is a negotiate-arbitrate model - is far from the finish line in the battle to reel in the power of big tech.

In its decision, the independent arbitrator must consider: the direct value of news content, and how much money is directly made from ads around news content; indirect value - the value to the platforms of actually have the content there (a much harder prospect to measure); the cost of producing news; and whether the payment amount would place an undue burden on Facebook or Google.

Sims admits that value will be hard to measure, and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission doesn't have the data to do that. He says it is the ACCC's job to correct the imbalance in bargaining power, which is the core issue, rather than the regulator or government setting the price digital platforms should pay media companies.

"Value is very hard to work out. I'm sure both sides will have a go at it. You've got value, you've also got cost of journalism, and no undue burden. The three things are all equal," Sims tells The Australian Financial Review.

Rough industry estimates suggest Nine, owner of The Australian Financial Review, and News Corp could spend about $250 million a year on journalism, Australian Community Media and Seven West Media $100 million each, and Network Ten $50 million. The cost is substantial for independents such as Crikey, and regional networks such as Prime Media and WIN Corp.

Sims says it's the one tangible measure of the three important considerations to begin talks.

"The beauty of the cost of journalism is if the number comes out to be 1 per cent ... that's not very sensible," he says. "If it's 100 per cent of the cost of journalism, you'd say 'Well, there's no way the platforms should cover all the costs of journalism.'

"So you'd naturally go to 10, 20 or 30, I don't know what the right number is, but you can tell that they provide at least a framework to anchor any discussion of value."

Combining Nine, News Corp, Seven, Ten and ACM would get to at least $750 million a year. Factor in other organisations and spend on journalism would be $1 billion in Australia. Taking 20 per cent of that, $200 million, is a substantial amount of money, and that's before value of journalism to the platforms has been considered.

The cost of producing journalism will be easier to find, but Sims recognises the value can't just be based on cost.

"We all know that print, or these days online, does drive a lot of other media stories," says Sims. "I think newspaper stories do have a degree of importance here. But that's really making the point I'm making - that the parties are well placed to make those points."

Here's where it gets tricky. Value could be very substantial, depending on what it is measured. Google itself admits it sends more than 3 billion clicks to Australian news organisations each year and that is the limit of the value exchange. But would Google actually lose those 3 billion clicks if it didn't have any news, and another search platform did?

Sims says media companies will be able to ask for information from the tech companies in working out the value. The tech giants will not be able to rely on their own data when making their own case, without providing its information to news media businesses.

Sims and the government want to curb a major imbalance in bargaining power between Facebook and Google, and local media companies, with the primary goal of fair financial compensation for the value created for the digital giants by having journalism on their platforms.

"When you've got this level of imbalance in bargaining power, forcing negotiation, forcing mediation will get you so far. But, having that arbitration at the end does really even up the bargaining power," Sims says.

"The threat that arbitration is there - parties usually like to avoid arbitration where somebody else determines the outcome - might just drive a range of commercial deals."

The code will give digital platforms and media companies the opportunity to agree to a deal. If they do not, they will go through three months of mediation before moving to a binding final-offer arbitration where the independent arbitrator must choose an offer within 45 days.

Google and Facebook will have armies of lawyers combing through the draft code of conduct.

Why? Precedent. Regulators across the world are battling to deal with Facebook and Google's monopolistic powers, and if Sims' model works, you can bet the house the platforms will face similar regimes in other countries.

"Australia is seen as innovative in a legislative sense, in that our parliaments produce high-quality legislation in the field of arbitration," says Dr Sam Luttrell, international arbitration group partner at law firm Clifford Chance.

It may be that this code is followed, or may be that this code informs the way governments around the world approach these issues."

While the ACCC is to be commended, Luttrell says, the draft code raises complex legal issues: it is a coercive process and there may not be an appeal, which could see Facebook and Google challenge its constitutional validity; and the timetable of 45 days, for some extremely complex issues, is very short.

"There are checks and balances built into the model that are well conceived for the most part, and this is draft legislation, and draft legislation is never perfect, nor is, for that matter, the final act," Luttrell says.

Don't expect the code of conduct to be the end of Google and Facebook's efforts to not pay for news content.

They've got form of dodging attempts. When regulation was passed in Spain in October 2014 to have Google and other aggregators pay news publishers for products like GoogleNews, the US-based search giant was swift and brutal.

By mid-December 2014, less than a month before the legislation came into effect, Google simply shut down Google News.

'Internationally, there have been a number of attempts to make Google and Facebook pay for the use of journalistic content.

One French proposal required Google to pay for the use of snippets of news articles from French media companies.

Google reverted to showing only headlines of articles to avoid paying fees, resulting in the French competition regulator ordering Google to negotiate with French publishers. Those negotiations are ongoing.

Google Australia head of policy Lucinda Longcroft says the ACCC code is not grounded in commercial reality and continues the tech giant's line that there is no market power imbalance.

"In terms of the ACCC's report, as a premise we fundamentally disagree with the claim that there is a market power imbalance," Longcroft said during a Competition Policy International discussion. "In fact, the ACCC's and the government's own data showed that we are only a small part of the traffic that news publishers receive from Australian users.

"We are deeply concerned about the current draft of the code. It is heavy-handed intervention and does not reflect commercial reality."

Sims says the ACCC has learned from the experiences of Spain, France and Germany in coming up with its model, in that it's related to Google Search and Facebook News Feed, the core products of the two US giants.

"[Spain was] something that could be turned off. What we've done, we've learnt from that. In this we're applying it to all media, to all news items," he says.

Citing an economic study done of the Spanish experience, Google, in its submission to the ACCC's efforts to draw up a code of conduct in Australia, notes the negative effect of its decision.

"A reduction in the availability and visibility of news in online aggregation services like Google News particularly harms small and medium-sized publishers without established brands," the company argues on page 13 of its submission.

Yet, less than a page later, Google continues to reject the idea there is an imbalance in its relationships with media business.

"We do not accept that the current value exchange with NMBs [news media businesses] associated with search results reflects an imbalance in bargaining power."

Though Google News and Google Search are different products, the US tech giant is stating its decisions hurt small and medium publishers in Spain, yet it does not have more power in bargaining with media companies over search results, an area of its business where it is hugely dominant the world over.

"To the extent that there is a bargaining power imbalance between NMBs and Google, the bargaining framework should seek to correct that imbalance by creating negotiating conditions that would exist between two arms' length parties with equal bargaining power.

"It should not create a framework that creates a bargaining power imbalance or that requires Google to act against its commercial interests (for example, by requiring us to make payments for inputs that don't generate economic value)."

Here lies one of the key issues. Google still refuses to acknowledge it holds a dominant position - Sims, the ACCC and the government have long decided they, and Facebook, do - and the Alphabet-owned company believes journalism doesn't hold any value to it worth paying for.

They don't believe they should pay, so expect legal challenges to come.

However, Sims says defining news will be relatively easy for most. For example, Nine and News Corp would be put on the list, and once on the list, all of their journalism would be included.

"You get through the gate by producing core news, and that's defined as publicly significant issues, journalism that engages Australians in public debate, informs democratic decision-making, journalism relating to community and local events," Sims says.

"Any one of those headings gets you through the door, and once you're through the door ... then all their news produced by journalists is covered."

If Google and Facebook ran newsrooms, employed and paid thousands of journalists across Australia, then a code of conduct would not be necessary. But they don't do journalism.

Instead, the code seeks to remunerate the creators of journalism for the value Google and Facebook get from having it on their platforms.

The idea that news organisations have not adapted to change, with tech leaders essentially implying the media industry are a bunch of Luddites, is a naive world view that sycophantically follows an adage that tech can only create good and should be taken up without care for the consequences on society.

It fails to look at the ways journalism has constantly evolved its model.

Technology is a net benefit to the world and its progress, but its use needs to be purposeful and critiqued like any other element of human evolution.

The ACCC's code is about a level playing field in an environment dominated by global giants. It doesn't appear Google and Facebook are going to accept that lying down.

It may be that this code is followed, or may be that this code informs the way governments around the world approach these issues."

While the ACCC is to be commended, Luttrell says, the draft code raises complex legal issues: it is a coercive process and there may not be an appeal, which could see Facebook and Google challenge its constitutional validity; and the timetable of 45 days, for some extremely complex issues, is very short.

"There are checks and balances built into the model that are well conceived for the most part, and this is draft legislation, and draft legislation is never perfect, nor is, for that matter, the final act," Luttrell says.

Don't expect the code of conduct to be the end of Google and Facebook's efforts to not pay for news content.

They've got form of dodging attempts. When regulation was passed in Spain in October 2014 to have Google and other aggregators pay news publishers for products like GoogleNews, the US-based search giant was swift and brutal.

By mid-December 2014, less than a month before the legislation came into effect, Google simply shut down Google News.

'Internationally, there have been a number of attempts to make Google and Facebook pay for the use of journalistic content.

One French proposal required Google to pay for the use of snippets of news articles from French media companies.

Google reverted to showing only headlines of articles to avoid paying fees, resulting in the French competition regulator ordering Google to negotiate with French publishers. Those negotiations are ongoing.

Google Australia head of policy Lucinda Longcroft says the ACCC code is not grounded in commercial reality and continues the tech giant's line that there is no market power imbalance.

"In terms of the ACCC's report, as a premise we fundamentally disagree with the claim that there is a market power imbalance," Longcroft said during a Competition Policy International discussion. "In fact, the ACCC's and the government's own data showed that we are only a small part of the traffic that news publishers receive from Australian users.

"We are deeply concerned about the current draft of the code. It is heavy-handed intervention and does not reflect commercial reality."

Sims says the ACCC has learned from the experiences of Spain, France and Germany in coming up with its model, in that it's related to Google Search and Facebook News Feed, the core products of the two US giants.

"[Spain was] something that could be turned off. What we've done, we've learnt from that. In this we're applying it to all media, to all news items," he says.

Citing an economic study done of the Spanish experience, Google, in its submission to the ACCC's efforts to draw up a code of conduct in Australia, notes the negative effect of its decision.

"A reduction in the availability and visibility of news in online aggregation services like Google News particularly harms small and medium-sized publishers without established brands," the company argues on page 13 of its submission.

Yet, less than a page later, Google continues to reject the idea there is an imbalance in its relationships with media business.

"We do not accept that the current value exchange with NMBs [news media businesses] associated with search results reflects an imbalance in bargaining power."

Though Google News and Google Search are different products, the US tech giant is stating its decisions hurt small and medium publishers in Spain, yet it does not have more power in bargaining with media companies over search results, an area of its business where it is hugely dominant the world over.

"To the extent that there is a bargaining power imbalance between NMBs and Google, the bargaining framework should seek to correct that imbalance by creating negotiating conditions that would exist between two arms' length parties with equal bargaining power.

"It should not create a framework that creates a bargaining power imbalance or that requires Google to act against its commercial interests (for example, by requiring us to make payments for inputs that don't generate economic value)."

Here lies one of the key issues. Google still refuses to acknowledge it holds a dominant position - Sims, the ACCC and the government have long decided they, and Facebook, do - and the Alphabet-owned company believes journalism doesn't hold any value to it worth paying for.

They don't believe they should pay, so expect legal challenges to come.

However, Sims says defining news will be relatively easy for most. For example, Nine and News Corp would be put on the list, and once on the list, all of their journalism would be included.

"You get through the gate by producing core news, and that's defined as publicly significant issues, journalism that engages Australians in public debate, informs democratic decision-making, journalism relating to community and local events," Sims says.

"Any one of those headings gets you through the door, and once you're through the door ... then all their news produced by journalists is covered."

If Google and Facebook ran newsrooms, employed and paid thousands of journalists across Australia, then a code of conduct would not be necessary. But they don't do journalism.

Instead, the code seeks to remunerate the creators of journalism for the value Google and Facebook get from having it on their platforms.

The idea that news organisations have not adapted to change, with tech leaders essentially implying the media industry are a bunch of Luddites, is a naive world view that sycophantically follows an adage that tech can only create good and should be taken up without care for the consequences on society.

It fails to look at the ways journalism has constantly evolved its model.

Technology is a net benefit to the world and its progress, but its use needs to be purposeful and critiqued like any other element of human evolution.

The ACCC's code is about a level playing field in an environment dominated by global giants. It doesn't appear Google and Facebook are going to accept that lying down.

urn:contentItem:5Y9G-8901-F0JP-W4GW-00000-00Sims warns on Big Tech growth2020-02-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:19ZLexisNexisMARKETWATCHPg. 26Sims warns on Big Tech growthRichard Gluyas

The explosive acquisition-fuelled growth of the world's large digital platforms is posing a significant challenge for competition authorities, Rod Sims says.

Mr Sims, chairman of the Australian Competition & Consumer Commission, called on global competition regulators to work together to meet this and other challenges, and consider whether traditional approaches to assessing mergers were withstanding the test of time.

"It is easy to suggest our markets would be more competitive if YouTube and DoubleClick were separate to Google, and if Instagram and WhatsApp were separate to Facebook," he said in a keynote speech at International Competition Network's merger workshop in Melbourne on Thursday.

"But predicting the future competitive effect of such acquisitions before they occur is extremely difficult.

"This illustrates the difficulties when you only have nascent competitors, or competitors in related markets." An ACCC inquiry resulted in Australia becoming one of the first countries in the world to develop broad reforms for the leading digital platforms, after Mr Sims said Google and Facebook had "almost unfettered market power" with a significant impact on consumers.

Under the Morrison Government's response to the inquiry, the ACCC will oversee the establishment of a new code to address the power imbalance between the platforms and media companies in Australia.

Steps will also be taken to ensure media businesses and digital platforms operate on a more regulatory footing, and that local journalism is supported.

While Mr Sims said be believed the Australian economy was too concentrated, and it was sometimes extremely difficult to challenge proposed mergers.

Competition authorities, he said, often felt like they were "on the back foot", seeking evidence about the unknown future world when much of the relevant knowledge and evidence was held by the parties to the transaction.

Previous decisions of the Federal Court and the Australian Competition Tribunal suggested there was an added challenge - the considerable weight given to the testimony of senior executives from the merger parties when pre-merger internal company documents showed a different story.

The ACCC this month lost a significant legal challenge to its efforts to block the $15bn merger between TPG and Vodafone, which involves the combination of Australia's third and fourth-largest telcos.

"My sense is that courts in some other jurisdictions are more sceptical of self-serving testimony by the merger parties," Mr Sims said.

"The challenge applies to all merger reviews but is even greater when the market environment is rapidly evolving and incumbents are acquiring emerging and innovative new players." The ACCC chief said competition authorities could help each other out with these challenges, particularly in matters involving global firms with complex and far-reaching operations.

Google's proposed $US2bn acquisition of smartwatch maker Fitbit, which some regulators were actively considering, was a key example.

"It's a very important matter," Mr Sims said.

In the meantime, the ACCC was looking at some of the key areas of difference with overseas counterparts, including different measures used to challenge anti-competitive mergers such as abuse of market power provisions or attempted monopoly provisions.

Some jurisdictions also allowed courts to start with the premise that increased concentration would cause a lessening in competition, while greater weight was given to the views of competition authorities and their merger guidelines in recognition of their expertise.

The "inherent bias and unreliability" of information created after the deal was agreed was also a consideration, and there was a focus - like in Australia - on the difficult task of determining what was likely to happen to the target company in the future rather than the immediate competitive effects.

Mr Sims said the Australian system was out of place compared to the formal, mandatory and suspensory regimes in many countries."We assess the vast majority of mergers under a voluntary and informal merger review process," he said.

urn:contentItem:5W4D-KKW1-DXH2-60YF-00000-00Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc at JPMorgan Global Technology, Media and Communications Conference - Final2019-05-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:25:19ZLexisNexis051419a12501857.757Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc at JPMorgan Global Technology, Media and Communications Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Christopher S. Ripley

Sinclair Broadcast Group, Inc. - President & CEO

* Lucy A. Rutishauser

Sinclair Broadcast Group, Inc. - Senior VP & CFO

Conference Call Participants

* Alexia Skouras Quadrani

JP Morgan Chase & Co, Research Division - MD and Senior Analyst

Presentation

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI, MD AND SENIOR ANALYST, JP MORGAN CHASE & CO, RESEARCH DIVISION: Good morning. I think we'll get started here. For those of you who don't know me, I'm Alexia Quadrani, the Media Analyst at JPMorgan. And we're very pleased to have Sinclair here with us today. I'm very pleased to welcome Chris Ripley, the President and CEO of Sinclair; and Lucy Rutishauser, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Thank you both very much for coming.

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY, PRESIDENT & CEO, SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.: Thanks, Alexia.

Questions and Answers

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: I think we'll just kick it off with some questions on your recent transaction and then we could jump into the core business. You recently announced the acquisition of 21 regional sports networks from Disney that were previously owned by Fox. Can you provide us a brief overview of the transaction and what assets you're actually purchasing?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: So it's certainly a transformative transaction in every respect of the word. It's a $10.6 billion acquisition, $9.6 billion after you adjust for minority Interest. The headline purchase multiple is very attractive at 6.5x and it's 5.5x after you adjust for the step-up in tax basis, which has an NPV of about $1.5 billion. And that does not include any cost synergies which we think will be significant here over time amounting to over $100 million on a run rate basis. It's the largest portfolio of RSNs in the country. So it gets us into the RSN business, into the sports business in a big way with a scale platform, has 14 MLB teams, 16 NBA teams and 12 NHL teams. And we've also set it up so that it has a separate credit silo and capital structure so that we can bring on strategic partners in the future, who just want to get RSN exposure.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: I guess, with these RSNs, you're purchasing the largest portfolio of regional sports networks in the market. Can you talk about the advantages of the combination of Sinclair's broadcast business with the RSNs?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: So we have been focused on sports for the last 4, 5 years as a means to create a sustainable and profitable business for ourselves in this changing video landscape. We've always been very strong in news. We are the largest news producer -- local news producer in the U.S. in terms of volume. And when we looked at what was happening in the marketplace with the increase of the peak TV phenomenon that is often much talked about, I first started with cable companies creating more and more original program and more and more general entertainment, now increasingly big tech coming in with incremental dollars creating seemingly unlimited supply of general entertainment. We knew we wanted to move into an area that would be more sustainable for us and that is really news and sports. And adding this portfolio to our news portfolio makes us the preeminent local sports and news company in the country. And the portfolios are very complimentary. The operation of an RSN is very similar to a TV station. They have 3 main functions: administration, production and ad sales. Those are things that we do at our stations every day. And as I mentioned earlier, we haven't factored any specific synergies in on the cost side, but there definitely will be some as we plug in this very complimentary portfolio into our platform.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: Two common concerns we often hear about RSNs, in general, is the high exposure to the pay TV affiliate fees given the decline in the ecosystem subscribers and the risk that the MVPDs will increasingly seek to tier sports networks to pass on the high cost to consumer. So I guess, can you talk broadly about how you

(technical difficulty)

of risk factors?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: This was obviously something we did a lot of work on, and major part of the transaction was understanding the strength of the product and the product is incredibly strong. As I mentioned earlier, sports and news are the place you want to be in terms of linear live viewing. They've massively outperformed every other genre in just about every metric of viewership that you can look at. And this product is, in many respects, must have product for the distributors and they will look to continue bringing this to their subscribers. I'm also, I think, very hardened by the fact that the main competitor, the Liberty group that competed against us, did have support from the 3 largest distributors in their bid, which all we need to do here for this to be a home run, no pun intended, is to get status quo renewals. That's it. It's not a high bar. And we know at the end of the day this is a very strong product, so we're very confident that it will not be tiered and it will be renewed.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: As you mentioned previously, you have been investing in a lot of sports assets recently, including you -- I think you own Ring of Honor, Tennis Channel and some high school sports as well. Do you see an opportunity to distribute some of this content on the RSNs longer term?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: There definitely is a synergy between all of our various sports outlets. There will be content sharing that goes on between them. We do a nice little business today in high school sports, for instance, which is sometimes even outrates the broadcast prime time on some of our stations. That content is directly relevant to regional audiences at the RSNs. Tennis content certainly would be relevant. Wrestling would be relevant. So we haven't figured out exactly how that will all interplay. Once we get in and start operating, we'll be able to figure that part out. But again, additional upside.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: And how about on the cost synergy side, I think you flagged $100 million over 5 years. Is there any additional color you can give us in terms of timing or where you'll see these savings?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: So the $100 million over the next 5 years is a very conservative number. It doesn't kick-in in year 1. But after year 1, there will be some significant programming agreements that roll off that will start to impact year 2 and onward. And the production technology that's being used at the RSNs is about 10 years old. And so there is a fairly substantial opportunity to modernize the technology that's used to produce these games and make them more efficient, while at the same time upgrading the user experience and the actual quality of production. And that will generate additional savings, which will roll out over the next 5 years and reach that $100 million number. We think there will be opportunities above and beyond that, as I mentioned, just sort of in blocking and tackling in administration, add sales and the like but that hasn't been quantified yet.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: Right now, the RSNs are primarily distributed to the legacy virtual MVPD -- the legacy MVPDs. As the distribution landscape shifts in the coming years, I guess how are you thinking about the potential carriage on the digital platforms? And how might this be sort of impacted by league restrictions?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Well, there has been a -- the vastest part of the business has been the virtual MVPDs, the streamers. And the Fox RSNs have gone from no subscribers to 5 million subscribers on virtual MVPDs over the last few years. And as I said, by far the fastest part, a growing part of the business, and I think that will continue. And we're seeing the bundle transform to a more streaming set-top-box-free-type experience and I expect that will continue. In terms of the leagues, well, we've met with all the leagues before we agreed to buy this asset. And the leagues are very much aligned with the RSNs as local partners. The RSNs need the leagues and leagues need the RSNs to succeed. They need them to do all the local production. They need them to distribute the games to their consumers in the market. And they need them to make the user or the viewer experiences as good as possible. And so there is a shared sense of success there with the leagues. And I expect, from my conversations, to be able to secure whatever rights are needed in the future to continue to grow local audiovisual consumption of any type, whether it's a new technology like VR or AR that -- those that will be the dominion of the RSNs going forward as a partnership with the league.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: Even before this deal, as you know, you guys announced the Marquee Sports Network with the Chicago Cubs, can you talk about this partnership and how you could be a model perhaps for your relationship with other teams?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: The Cubs deal was a great deal. And as you point out, a good example about how to align interest. The Cubs have significant -- have a significant stake in the success of that network. And they were one of the few teams in this country that could have gone on their own and did this all by themselves, but they chose to partner with Sinclair. And I think that just in onto its own, tells you something about what we bring to the table. And in terms of alignment of interest, the Fox RSN portfolio already comes with significant team ownership across several of the MLB teams, and that is a trend as we renew contracts. We will increasingly give the teams upside in their individual RSNs and that aligns interest. It also variabilizes more the cost structure and that will be a trend going forward.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: I'm moving on to sort of the core, I guess, the core legacy business, the core business. Coming into this year, there has been some concern that core advertising was slow to recover from the elections, similar to 2017. You've recently stated you expect core to be up in 2019. Why do you think the ad market has come in better than expected?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Well, it wasn't really better than expected for us.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: For you -- for us, perhaps I should say for us.

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: I guess that the market was...

LUCY A. RUTISHAUSER, SENIOR VP & CFO, SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.: Skeptical.

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Skeptical. And rightly so, last year, the industry got off to a bad start. The first 2 quarters were very negative, and we've rebounded off of that in the back half of the year, we had political. And then that core strength or relative strength, if you will, has continued on into this year. So we were flattish in Q1 and will be flattish up in Q2. And then in the back half of the year, you've got the benefit of lapping the ChryslerFiat issues that dogged us last year as a major advertiser. And then you also have the benefit of not have -- of getting the spots back from political, the political crowd out that depressed core in the back half of last year.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: And auto is the category that some of the competitors have flags under pressure giving lower vehicle sales this year. You stated you expect it to increase in '19. Can you talk about some of the drivers on this, including maybe past investments you've made into the category?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: So auto came off a 5- or 6-year growth run after the great recession, just quarter-after-quarter growth. The market's going through sort of a consolidation period right now in auto. So you have seen some weakness. And we have relatively done better because we've hired category specialists. And those category specialists know the business of an auto dealership Tier 3 supplier. They know that business better than our average -- when they add the average, the seller would know it. And they come in with specialty solutions and products that focus on generating sales for the advertiser, not just on selling spots. So that approach has been successful in the marketplace and it's why you're seeing us outperform others in that category.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: We keep hearing all sorts of local advertising-driven companies talk about the services category, which has been really strong. I think Lamar just highlighted it a few minutes ago actually. Both you and your competitors continue to say it's red hot right now. I guess, what's driving the strength behind this?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Services has definitely been a great category for us. The 3 areas that have really driven that are legal, insurance and banking. And legal category has -- is one of our larger categories. It's always been strong for us and continues to grow. And insurance and banking can ebb and flow, but it's particularly strong right now.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: I guess, switching to political. Can you talk about your outlook for 2020 as well as, I guess, 2019, given the potential for early primary spending?

LUCY A. RUTISHAUSER: Sure. So we are very excited about 2020's prospects. If you think about, right now, the number of people that have entered the race on the democratic side, actually this number's going to blow your way. Not all of them will come to the table there with money, but there are now over 700 people who have registered on the democratic side to run for presidency across the country. So yes -- and look the first people were already throwing their name into the ring the day after Congress was sworn in, which is very early in the process over a year before the first primaries get aired. So we have that. When you look at the states that were lean in 2016, we're in 7 or 8 of the 10 lean states. And we're there in a big way with a lot of the news. So we're in the swing states. You've got a lot of people running. We already know there's a lot of issue, national issue money, not to mention local issue money that's coming forward. And then when you look historically, and you've heard us talk about our growth initiatives, and one of those is expanding our news dayparts because that's the first place that political money goes. So we've spent a lot of time focusing on our local news, adding dayparts and we actually saw the first return of that in 2018 when we increased our share of the political dollars in our markets. So I'm going to throw a stat out for you. Do not change your models for this stat, but some of the third-party research is now saying that 2020's political funding could be 70% over 2016's. Again don't build that into your models for us quite yet, but I think it really just goes to show what we have to look forward to and we're still very early in the process.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: That's amazing. I have got a ton more questions, but since it's such a full room, I want to stop for a minute and see if there is any questions from the audience. I think we have one right here and one over there. Could you just wait for 1 second? The mic will come because of the webcast. Okay, second row.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: So on the RSNs, assuming the deal passes the regulatory scrutiny and goes through, do you expect there would be a cap on the number of RSNs you could eventually own? And then second, if you were to buy more RSNs, would financing come exclusively from the RSN subsidiary? Or could that include cash, debt or others from the parent Sinclair?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: From a precedent standpoint, they're -- the market at the DOJ is defined as cable and cable sports. So -- but from a precedential standpoint, you wouldn't expect there to be any limitation on the number of RSNs any one player could own. But that will, obviously, be up to the DOJ to determine. They look at things on a case-by-case basis, but precedence would say no to your answer. And then in terms of financing, since we did set this up so that they each have their own capital structure, we'd anticipate that most of the financing will come from the RSN silo as not to totally exclude the notion that some amount of, say, equity with more equity would come from the Sinclair side. But going forward, these 2 divisions, if you will, or silos as we're calling them, are set up to pursue their own path for capital raising.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: The third row.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Is there any chance that the -- in siloing the capital structures that, that won't be achievable at the end of the day? Is that -- so is there any chance that, that structure would...

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: It's really been achieved. So we haven't closed yet, but the -- all the financing is fully committed to and so it's very, very unlikely that it won't be achieved, I guess, is the answer to your question.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Can you describe the STIRR initiative and how that's performing?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: STIRR is our foyer into the AVOD segment. It's gone well ahead of expectations. It's been a great launch for us and it's in primarily focused on user expansion at this point and well ahead of its stats as it relates to where we thought it would be. Really the key to STIRR, as we see it, is that it gives you both a linear lean back experience and VoD experience. So a lot of streaming apps or experiences, they just focus on demand. Whereas this gives you the ability to channel surf just like you would on a normal standard traditional experience, but also seamlessly jump into on-demand. And the other really interesting thing about STIRR is that it focuses on local. So the most watched channel on STIRR is STIRR CITY. So depending on what city you're in, you will get a customized channel for your location, which will include things like your local news and other locally focused programming and that happens to be the most watched channel on STIRR today. So that's really the secret sauce of STIRR is combining linear and on-demand, and also giving you linear -- local programming. Plus right now, we're above 30 national channels on top of that. So, so far, so good.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: Is it too early to really tell how big the opportunity could be down the road? I know you just recently launched.

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Yes, it's probably too early. But I will note that Viacom is making hay with Pluto, doing quite well there. They have very high expectations for that platform and we think STIRR could follow a similar path.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: I'll be one here and then -- okay, go ahead in the back. It's one in the back, you can take it.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: I noticed the way that the other media sort of coverage you as a company is, let's just say, unfair at times or at least that there is an agenda there seems to be. Do you view that as an asset or liability? How do you think about that as you make strategic decisions for the company itself?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Do I view it as an asset or a liability, that's a good question. Look, it is what it is. We don't let that affect our strategic path going forward. We're going to do what's in the best interest of the shareholders to create value, and the coverage will be -- what the coverage is.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Can you comment on the financial trends of the RSNs? There's obviously been some concerns of late so maybe that would be helpful.

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Well, the announcement that we made in terms of the acquisition multiple is what we think will be the trough year for the RSNs in terms of where EBITDA is. So we expect growth on a go-forward basis for -- from calendar '19 and onward.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: Since you're getting big in sports -- bigger in sports, any plans for exploring sports betting?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Yes. Sports betting, we think, is going to be a big tailwind for this acquisition. When you take a look at the impact of what daily fantasy did for the NFL viewership was quite substantial and we would have made the acquisition regardless of whether there was a sports betting opportunity. But in this case, sports betting is spreading across the country. As I think you all know, 30-odd states are looking at it or have either made it legal or looking at it now. And we think the RSNs will be a prime beneficiary of this trend. And that will benefit the RSNs really in 3 significant ways. Number one is it'll increase engagement and in terms of tonnage, the RSNs do over 5,000 live events. The Fox RSNs do over 5,000 live events a year and so a lot on the regular-season games and if there is a reason for people to tune in because they are gaming or they are actually betting on the outcome of the game and the RSNs will really benefit from that increased engagement, that engagement will be monetized through additional advertising by having more impressions. And then also we will benefit from a new category of advertiser coming in. So the actual betting houses themselves will want to advertise in these games because that's their target audience, and that's a brand-new category, which is expected to be multibillion dollars entering the ecosystem and putting additional pressure on the pricing of the inventory. And then the third main benefit that we see from sports betting is the phenomenon of in-game betting, which you can see in Europe has become a substantial part of the marketplace and we think the U.S. will follow that same trend and people will ultimately be doing their gaming integrated with the media and doing it on a prop, not just on a game outcome basis but on a prop basis and a play-by-play basis. And that sort of engagement, we will -- we think will benefit us in terms of engagement, but also in terms of ancillary revenue opportunities.

UNIDENTIFIED ANALYST: You will then develop your own path for in-game there? That's...

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Well, we'll have to see. We're certainly going to experiment with different ways. There's already RSNs that are putting out 2 feeds. One gaming-centered feed that has, right now, it's a sweepstakes-site style betting to experiment with and we'll have to see whether we pursue a platform or not that, that's yet to be determined. But I think as a media company within this space, whether you have your platform or not, you're going to have many opportunities to benefit from this.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: Let me jump back in with a couple of more questions because I know we're going to get run out of time. The DOJ recently held a forum to discuss how it views the local ad market. Did you get a sense at all that the broadcasters made any headway in their argument that the market should be redefined to include cable and digital advertising?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Look, it was a great session. I thought all the panelists did an excellent job, especially on the second day. Specifically, I give my hats off to Dave Lougee, who handled the panel that specifically talked about the market definition between broadcast and cable and online video. There was also participation on that panel from Comcast and Facebook. And that panel in particular was a resounding success, I guess, from my perspective. But also, everyone in unison agreed that those markets have now blended together from an advertising perspective, as we've been living that for quite some time. And so I think it achieved the goals that the industry had hoped, and it'll just be up to the DOJ now to see what they do with it.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: I guess, I was going to ask you what are the next steps? Is it waiting for the DOJ to do something? Or is there anything else you guys can in the broader industry can do?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: I think the ball is really in the DOJ's court to decide whether they're ready to make a shift in precedence or not.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: And then turning to the national cab, I feel like we've been discussing this for a very long time. Do you anticipate that the FCC will look at this in 2019?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Well, the NPRM has been out there for a while. We know the FCC would like to do something and they've been looking at various alternatives. The industry, the NAB, pretty much all the players have gotten behind the notion of a 78% cap and there's a decent amount of momentum around that idea. And again, I don't know exactly what the FCC is thinking, but if I had to guess, they probably will try to act on that NPRM. And the industry consensus right now is 78%.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: Okay, I'm going to sneak in one more before we run out of time. I guess, can you discuss where you are in the Tennis Channel in terms of national distribution advertising and the launch of an international

DTC product?

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: So Tennis Channel has been a phenomenal success for us. We've over doubled the homes that it's now viewable in since acquisition about 3 years ago. It significantly increased its distribution revenues and it's set to have a banner year next year. And the viewership, as I have stated on a few of our calls has been sort of slow in coming as we've added Nielsen and Nielsen's panels are not nearly as robust as Comscore. So it's taking a while for the increased distribution to translate into increased viewership, but we're starting to see that now. Fairly significant gains in year-over-year viewerships starting to hit the tape for the Tennis Channel, which is encouraging to see. And it seems like that asset now is starting to fire on all cylinders. In terms of the international DTC opportunity, we have mentioned that we're incubating an international play that should launch near the end of this year and European territories will be the first target. So we're going to build on the success that we've had with our OTT app here in the U.S. that does both TV Everywhere plus direct-to-consumer and start launching the Tennis Channel in foreign territories.

ALEXIA SKOURAS QUADRANI: All right. Well, we're out of time. Thank you very much for coming and joining us.

CHRISTOPHER S. RIPLEY: Thank you, Alexia.
